title: transformers_(live_action)
body:
A general tag for the live-action [[Transformers]] films. They are often referred to as the Bayverse or simply Bayformers by fans due to their heavy association with director [[Michael Bay]], even after he stepped down as director following the fifth film. The series consists of:

* [i][[Transformers (2007 movie)|]][/i]
* [i][[Transformers: Revenge of The Fallen]][/i]
* [i][[Transformers: Dark of the Moon]][/i]
* [i][[Transformers: Age of Extinction]][/i]
* [i][[Transformers: The Last Knight]][/i]
* [i][[Bumblebee (movie)|]][/i]
* [i][[Transformers: Rise of the Beasts]][/i]

These tags also apply to content exclusive to the spin-offs and adaptations of the films, such as the video games, tie-in comics, and toylines.

title: bumblebee_(movie)
body:
The sixth live-action [[Transformers]] film, and a continuity reboot to the series. It was originally planned to be a prequel movie connected with [[transformers (live action)|Michael Bay's Transformer movies]] but it was later changed to be a reboot due to consistently negative fan reception to the Bay movies.

Directed by Travis Knight and starring Hailee Steinfeld and [[John Cena]], the 2018 movie follows [[Bumblebee (transformers)|]] after he escapes from the Decepticons and lands on Earth during the 1980s, where he befriends a young punk girl named [[Charlie Watson]]. The movie received positive reviews by fans and critics due to its story, characters and usage of G1-inspired designs for the robots.

A sequel, titled [b][[Transformers: Rise of the Beasts]][/b], was announced for a June 2023 release, introducing elements of [[Beast Wars]]  into the films.

title: gachimuchi
body:
[b]Gachimuchi[/b] (or [b]Wrestling Series[/b]) is a [[meme]]tic universe which revolves around male porn actors (mostly from Can-Am Productions) flexing their muscles, wearing and doing [[BDSM]] stuff, and doing [i]gay pants wrestling[/i] (from where the tag gets its name, "Gachimuchi" meaning [i]buff man in underwear[/i] in Japan) in homoerotic films taken out of context.

The meme originated when [[Niconico]] members uploaded a video of [[Billy Herrington]] and [[Danny Lee]] doing [i]pants wrestling[/i] under the title "[b]本格的 ガチムチパンツレスリング[/b]" ([i]Professional Pant Wrestler Fighting Seriously[/i]) in 2007. This later spawned tons of parodies around [i]pants wrestling[/i] and related people that acted in non-pants wrestling porn with a pants wrestler as an actor in the aforementioned porno.

It is often paired with [[Manatsu no yo no Inmu]] (Inmu-chu) and [[Kuso Miso Technique]] ([[Yaranaika]]) as the "Holy Homo Trinity" (御三ゲイ), since all three were well-known homoerotic memes that were popular within Japanese communities in the 2000s.

While Gachi parodies did find their way outside of Japan, most prominently between 2007 and 2012, it wasn't until later from 2015 onwards that it spread even further under the name [b]gachiGASM[/b] (named after the BTTV emotes for [[Twitch.tv]] featuring Billy Herrington's iconic face) and spawned countless more sub-memes.

While Gachimuchi's popularity has decreased with the Japanese (being supplanted by Inmu on Niconico), Gachimuchi is currently extremely popular internationally. On the Chinese video site [[Bilibili]], the Chinese started making parodies of their popular TV series and movies, and also parodies of Japanese anime. Many Gachimuchi videos became some of the most viewed videos on Bilibili (one having had over 5 million views). This popularity would, however, lead to Bilibili attempting to squash the community on the site, leading to it dispersing across other Chinese communities. It also became popular in Russia, where a live-action parody and various music remix was made of it in spite of the country's anti-homosexual laws.

The tag used for Gachimuchi on Bilibili and in Chinese communities is [b]哲♂学 (Learning♂Philosophy)[/b].

h4. List of popular Gachimuchi characters

title: 1917_(movie)
body:
[b]1917[/b] is a 2019 [[united_kingdom|British]] [[war]] film directed and produced by Sam Mendes, who co-wrote it with Krysty Wilson-Cairns. 

Partially inspired by stories told to Mendes by his paternal grandfather Alfred about his service during [[World War I]], the film takes place after the [[germany|German]] retreat to the Hindenburg Line during Operation Alberich, and follows two British soldiers, [[William Schofield]] ("George MacKay":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_MacKay_(actor)) and [[Thomas Blake]] ("Dean-Charles Chapman":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dean-Charles_Chapman), in their mission to deliver an important message to call off a doomed offensive attack. 

Mark Strong, Andrew Scott, Richard Madden, Claire Duburcq, Colin Firth, and Benedict Cumberbatch also star in supporting roles.

title: 1408_(movie)
body:
1408 is a 2007 American psychological horror film based on Stephen King's 1999 short story of the same name. It is directed by Mikael Håfström and stars John Cusack and Samuel L. Jackson. The film was released in the United States on June 22, 2007.

title: arius_squad_(blue_archive)
body:
In [[Blue Archive]], Arius Squad is one of the clubs at Arius Satellite School.

An elite team formerly consisting of five members hand-picked by Beatrice, yet only seen by her as mere pawns ready to be disposed of at any time. Commonly referred to as Squad, they were responsible for the assassination attempt of [[Seia (blue archive)|]] and the attack during the signing of the Eden Treaty. [spoilers]If [[Azusa (blue archive)|]] is also present, please add [[spoilers]].[/spoilers]
 
Being a faction tag, this should only be used when all members of the group are present and equally in focus.

h4. Members

* [[Saori (blue archive)|]]

* [[Misaki (blue archive)|]]

Also well-known for his [[Fate/Grand Order]] [i]Learn With Manga![/i] series (pool #10385) featuring an "annoying looking" version of [[fujimaru_ritsuka_(female)|female Fujimaru Ritsuka]], which was later known as "Gudako".

title: frankenstein
body:
A novel written by Mary Shelley. It tells the story of a man named [[Victor Frankenstein]], who wanted to create life from dead tissue.

The novel has been adapted to film multiple times, most notably in 1931 by Universal Pictures, from where many depictions of [[Frankenstein's monster]] come.

h4. See also

* [[Bride of Frankenstein]]

* [http://knarf.english.upenn.edu/Text/text.html](The Pennsylvania Electronic Edition)

title: go_gun-hee
body: A major supporting character from the South Korean multimedia franchise [[Solo Leveling]]. An S-rank hunter who retired from active duty due to his advanced age (80+) and became the chairman of the Korean Hunters Association. He is held in very high regard by the wider South Korean hunter community, even among hunters from other guilds, who are his competitors for lucrative gates.

title: hirai_yukari
body:
A character of [[Shakugan no Shana]]. [[Shana]] takes over Yukari's identity using the remains of her "Power of Existence" (life force) after she became a Torch (an entity replacement for a human whose Power of Existence has been significantly depleted) and eventually disappeared.

To distinguish Yukari from Shana, one must consider the following:

* Yukari's eyes were purple; Shana in neutral form has brown eyes.
* Yukari had small [[twintails]]. Shana rarely wears them, but when she does, they are in huge tresses.
* Yukari did not have the [[ahoge]] Shana has.
* Yukari did not wear [[thighhighs]] like Shana does.

title: arashio_(kancolle)
body:
[[Kantai Collection]]'s personification of the Japanese destroyer [i]Arashio[/i]. Character design by [[Konishi (koconatu)|]], voiced by [[Miyakawa Wakana]].

She has [[long_hair|long]] [[brown hair]] and [[brown_eyes|brown]] or [[yellow_eyes|yellow]] eyes. Her default outfit is the Konishi-design [i]Asashio[/i]-class uniform: a [[short_sleeves|short-sleeved]] [[white shirt]], a [[grey skirt]] with [[suspenders]], [[black socks|black]] [[kneehighs]], and grey-red [[rudder footwear]]. 

Her [[rigging]] consists of her real-life bridge and foremast to her back, a 12.7 cm twin [[handgun]] mount, and 61 cm quad handheld [[torpedo tubes]]. 

She is often giggling and trying to act sexy (like [[Kisaragi (Kancolle)|]]), but she looks more cute rather than sexy. 

The historical [i]Arashio[/i] was completed in December 1937 and sunk in March 1943 during the Battle of the Bismarck Sea.

title: arashio_kai_ni_(kancolle)
body: With her second remodel released in the 25th January 2017 update, she wears the uniform shared by the rest of the remodeled Asashio-class. Arashio's version consists of a [[long_sleeves|long-sleeved]] [[white shirt]] under a [[frilled_dress|frilled]] [[pinafore dress]] and [[black pantyhose]]. Her equipment consists of a hand-held [[ship turret|turret]], two [[torpedo|torpedo launchers]] [[thigh_strap|strapped]] to her thighs, a [[searchlight]] resembling a [[crime prevention buzzer]] and a [[daihatsu_(landing_craft)|daihatsu]] attached to her backpack straps.

A [[meme]] based on a panel from [[Grappler Baki]], in which [[Hanma Baki]] performs a [[one arm handstand]] in a sideways position with his other hand on his shoulder. Attempting to copy the pose became a popular challenge on [[TikTok]]. The meme overlaps with another which references a similar sideways position done by [[Kinnikuman]]'s [[Psychoman]].

title: bullpup
body:
A type of non-handgun [[gun|firearm]] configuration where the action is located behind the trigger group/housing and alongside the shooter's face, instead of in front as in conventional designs. This permits the [[weapon]] to be shorter for the same barrel length, improving maneuverability and reducing weight.

Basically, in a normal gun, the [[magazine (weapon)|]] is in front and the trigger is behind. In a bullpup firearm, the trigger is in front and the magazine is behind.

h4. Examples

* !post #6836035

title: gyan
body:
A fictional manned giant robot from the [[Gundam]] [[mecha]]verse. It first appeared in [[Mobile Suit Gundam]] from 1979. 

[b]YMS-15 Gyan[/b]

A grey, mono-eyed [[mecha|mobile suit]] that resembles a European medieval knight. It it outfitted with a [[rapier]]-like [[energy sword|beam saber]] and a round [[shield]] containing numerous missiles and hide mines. 

Piloted by [[M'Quve]].

title: z23_(azur_lane)
body:
[[Azur Lane]]'s depiction of the German destroyer [i]Z23[/i], lead ship of the 1936A-class. In the game and the fandom, she is often referred to as Nimi in reference to the Iroha order of her number.

In her base art, she wears a [[beret]] with a [[white ribbon]] wrapped around the rim, and a ribbon with an [[iron cross]] on the right side of her head. She has [[short hair|short]], [[brown hair]] with [[blue eyes]]. Her clothes consist of skin-tight under-layer, including [[bike shorts]], with a white [[double-breasted]] piece covering the front part of her body. Around her waist appears to be a combination of a coat and a [[showgirl skirt]], with [[gold trim]], a red inside, and a navy-blue outside. She wears [[black gloves|black]] [[elbow gloves]] with heavy duty [[white gloves]] over them. Her [[rigging]] consists of quadruple [[torpedo tubes]] attached to her back, and a handheld twin [[ship turret|turret]] mount housed inside mechanical, shark-like jaws.

title: ppd-40
body:
[[russian text|Russian:]] [b]Пистоле́т-пулемёт Дегтярёва[/b] (Degtyaryov machine pistol) 

PPD-40 is a [[Soviet]] [b][[submachine gun]][/b] chambered in 7.62×25mm Tokarev, originally designed in 1934 by "Vasily Degtyaryov":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vasily_Degtyaryov]. It had a conventional wooden stock without pistol grip, open bolt mechanism, and selective fire. It was replaced by the lower-cost [[PPSh-41]]. The later PPD models can utilize a 71-round [[drum magazine]].

h1. See also
* [[DP-27]]
* [[list of weapons]]
* [[PPD-40 (Girls' Frontline)]]
* [[PTRD-41]]
* [[RPD]]
* [[Suomi KP/-31]]
* Wikipedia entry: "PPD-40":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPD-40]

title: battle_scars
body:
“Battle Scars” is a collection of three stories about [[Russo-Ukrainian war|Russian full-scale invasion of Ukraine]].

The first is about Matya, describing the war through the eyes of a child.
The second is about Olena, based on the true story of a girl who “experiences the invisible scars of the Russian-Ukrainian war”. 
The third is the story of Ukrainian soldiers, one of whom is a veteran of the [[Russo-Ukrainian war|Russian-Ukrainian war]], known by his call-sign [[Grandpa Shinobi]].

""Battle Scars" is a story of people who can never be forgotten, and I hope it will remain in everyone’s hearts,” wrote manga author [[Kobayashi Niki]].

title: mikumikuplaylist
body:
A YouTube Short created by [[channel (caststation)]] featuring [[Hatsune Miku]] from [[Vocaloid]] that rapidly skips between several of her songs.
The fluid animation and colorful style caused it to go viral, and inspired artists to make their own versions.

Some notable elements are the [[media player interface]] with [[progress bar]], and the character interacting with the bounding box where the [[album_cover|album cover art]] normally goes.

h4. Videos
* !post #6134012: Original - post #6134012
* !post #7351118: Extended - post #7351118

h4. External Links
* [s]"Twitter: 初音ミク":[https://twitter.com/_caststation/status/1770037249628938473][/s] ("Archive.org":[https://web.archive.org/web/20240328090111/https://twitter.com/_CASTSTATION/status/1770037249628938473])
* [s]"YouTube: 39PLAYER":[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhk4IXVHDys][/s] ("Archive.org":[https://web.archive.org/web/20230311213653/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhk4IXVHDys])
* "YouTube: mikumikuplaylist v3.9":[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yOs73nkU_mM]

title: mc_(obey_me!)
body:
The protagonist of the [[obey_me!:_one_master_to_rule_them_all!|Obey Me!]] series of games. Their default name is Yuki, but this can be changed by the player along with their birthday at the start of the game. Their appearance, gender, and background are ambiguous and left up to the the player's preference.

In official illustrations and anime, they are depicted as a small, horned pink [[sheep]] with a [[neck_ribbon|bow]] [[neck_bell|bell]] around their neck.

title: fafnir_(fate)
body:
The [[Fate (series)|]] depiction of the evil [[dragon]] from Germanic and Norse mythology. Depending on the story either [[Siegfried (fate)|]] or [[Sigurd (fate)|]] eventually slayed Fafnir, with it being possible that they both killed different versions of the same dragon.

Siegfried gained [[dragon boy|dragon traits]] after bathing in Fafnir's blood. After [[Sieg (fate)|]] in turn obtained Siegfried's heart, he begins to be overwhelmed by the dragon blood, eventually fully changing into Fafnir's form. 

He also appears as an enemy in [[Fate/Grand Order]]'s [[Orleans (fate/grand order)|]] Singularity.

h4. External links
* "Type-Moon Wiki":https://typemoon.fandom.com/wiki/Fafnir

title: obey_me!:_one_master_to_rule_them_all!
body:
An ikemen romance simulation and RPG card mobile game for iOS and Android produced by NTT Solmare Corp. It is one of many otome games from a dating sim brand called Shall We Date? The player is a human exchange student at Devildom, a school in the underworld for demons, and is tasked with assisting the student council. There are currently 12 dateable characters with a group of brothers, avatars of the Seven Deadly Sins, at its core.

h4. In-Game Characters
h5.  Demon Brothers
([i]listed oldest to youngest[/i])
* [[lucifer_(obey_me!)|Lucifer]] (avatar of pride)
* [[mammon_(obey_me!)|Mammon]] (avatar of greed)
* [[leviathan_(obey_me!)|Leviathan]] (avatar of envy)
* [[satan_(obey_me!)|Satan]] (avatar of wrath)
* [[asmodeus_(obey_me!)|Asmodeus]] (avatar of lust)
* [[beelzebub_(obey_me!)|Beelzebub]] (avatar of gluttony)
* [[belphegor_(obey_me!)|Belphegor]] (avatar of sloth)

h5. Other Demons
* [[Diavolo (obey me!)|]]
* [[Barbatos (obey me!)|]]
* [[Mephistopheles (obey me!)|]]

h5. Angels
* [[luke_(obey_me!)|Luke]]
* [[simeon_(obey_me!)|Simeon]]
* [[raphael (obey me!)|Raphael]]

h5. Humans
* [[mC (Obey Me!)|Yuki]] (MC; player's character)
* [[Solomon (obey me!)|]]

h5. Other Characters
* Helene (human trapped in a painting)
* Thirteen (reaper)


h4. External Links

title: the_fast_and_the_furious_1
body:
The first film in [[Fast & Furious]] saga, released in [[2001]]. The film follows LAPD officer [[Brian O'Conner]], who goes undercover in the local street racing scene in search of a group of truck hijackers, where he crosses paths with [[Dominic Toretto]].

Particularly notable cars featured in this entry include Brian's [[Mitsubishi Eclipse]] and [[Toyota Supra Mk IV]], and Dom's [[Dodge Charger]].

This entry is known as [b]Wild Speed[/b] in Japan.

title: furious_7
body:
The 7th installment in [[Fast & Furious]] saga, released in [[2015]]. This was the last entry to feature [[Brian O'Conner]] due to Paul Walker's passing, with the character being sent off in the often-referenced [[The Last Ride (furious 7)|]] scene.

The film is not only notable for it's tribute to Walker, but also for extremely over-the-top stunts (including skydiving cars and making a [[W Motors Lykan HyperSport|Lykan HyperSport]] jump between [[skyscraper]]s), which far outdid any of the previous action scenes in the series.

This entry is known as [b]Wild Speed Sky Mission[/b] in Japan.

title: 2_fast_2_furious
body:
The second installment in [[Fast & Furious]] saga, released in [[2003]].

The most notable cars featured in this film are [[Brian O'Conner|Brian O'Conner's]] [[nissan skyline r34|R34]] [[Nissan Skyline GT-R]] and [[Suki (2 fast 2 furious)|Suki's]] [[Honda S2000]].

This entry is known as [b]Wild Speed X2[/b] in Japan.

title: nissan_skyline_r34
body:
The tenth generation of the [[Nissan Skyline]], produced from 1998 to 2000. Arguably one of the most recognizable iterations of the car.

This was the final Skyline generation to have a [[nissan skyline gt-r|GT-R]] variant. The GT-R badge would again be put on hiatus until 2009, when Nissan released the [[Nissan GT-R]] as a dedicated supercar and successor to the Skyline GT-R line.

The R34 had several appearances in popular media. In several [[Fast & Furious]] films it is driven by [[Brian O'Conner]], in [[Initial D]] it is driven by Hoshino Kozo, and in [[Wangan Midnight]] two R34s are driven by Yamamoto Kazuhiko and Goto Gen. It also remains a staple of many racing game rosters to this day, having also been the cover car for multiple [[Need for Speed]] games - namely [[Need for speed: underground|Underground]] and Payback.

title: toyota_supra_mk_iv
body:
The fourth generation of the [[Toyota Supra]], produced from 1993 to 2002. Easily the most iconic of the Supra models, the Mk IV is widely considered one of the best cars ever produced by [[Toyota]], and is often the most expensive 90s JDM halo car in the secondhand market.

The Mk IV Supra is most well known for it's appearance in the first [[Fast & Furious]] film, where it is the main car driven by [[Brian O'Conner]].

title: the_last_ride_(furious_7)
body:
Posts that reference the epilogue of [i][[Furious 7]][/i], in which [[Dominic Toretto]] has a final drive with [[Brian O'Conner]]. The scene was added during production to be a send-off to Brian's actor Paul Walker, who was tragically killed in a road accident partway through filming; it prominently features the Wiz Khalifa & Charlie Puth song "See You Again", which was also made as a tribute to Walker.

In the scene, Brian drives a white [[Toyota Supra Mk IV]] (owned by Walker personally before he passed), while Dom drives a grey [[Dodge Charger]]. Most parodies reference the part of the scene where the pair roll down their windows and say a final farewell before driving off in different paths.

title: luka_(honkai:_star_rail)
body:
Playable character in [[Honkai: Star Rail]].

An optimistic and carefree member of Wildfire. He is the renowned boxing champion of the Belobog Underworld with a mixed martial arts prowess. His enthusiasm inspires other people, especially children, to dream big. 

He has [[blue eyes]], [[short hair|short]] [[red hair]] that may extend [[hair between eyes|past his eyes]], and commonly tied into [[ponytail]].

h4. Profile
[expand]
An optimistic and carefree fighter with a mechanical arm. Skilled in mixed martial arts and is a Wildfire member.

From the fight cage to the battlefield, and from a fighter to a warrior, Luka uses his strength to protect the people of the Underworld.

He wishes to bring hope to others precisely because he had experienced despair himself.
[/expand]

title: headpiece
body:
A decorative type of headwear that is fitted around one's head (usually being fitted near/on the forehead) and doesn't fit the traditional definition of a crown, tiara, hairband, et cetera. A headpiece can be worn with a hat though is usually shown being worn on its own. Headpieces are usually depicted as jewelry, though it can be made out of nearly anything such as cloth, machinery, and so forth.

[[jeanne d'arc (fate)|Jeanne d'Arc]] from [[fate_(series)|Fate]] and [[yomi_(p&d)|Yomi]] from [[puzzle_&_dragons|Puzzle & Dragons]] are good examples of characters that wear a headpiece.

title: glowworm_(azur_lane)
body:
[[Azur Lane]]'s personification of the destroyer HMS [i]Glowworm[/i] (H92). Character design by [[Lino-Lin]], voiced by [[Igarashi Hiromi]]. 

She is portrayed with [[very long hair|very long]] [[green hair]] tied into [[twintails]] with yellow scrunchies, and [[green eyes]]. Her outfit consists of a [[white dress|white]] [[frilled dress]] underlayer with [[long sleeves]], and a [[double-breasted]] [[red dress]] overlayer with [[gold trim]] and a [[breast cutout]]. She also has a purplish blue [[necktie]] and a [[maid headdress]] of the same maroon color as her overlayer. She has a purplish-blue [[thighhighs]] with ribbons around the trim, and [[mary janes]] of the same maroon color.

She wields an [[anchor]] with a green [[searchlight]] attached via a ribbon. Her skill "Meteor Slam" and several of her lines mention ramming, an allusion to when she rammed [[Admiral Hipper (azur lane)|Admiral Hipper]] in her final battle.

title: howto:translate
body:
Translating on Danbooru is one major way to contribute, since "many images":[/posts?tags=translation_request] need translating. Danbooru utilizes a unique soft-translation system that enables translations to appear on images which are written in their native, non-English languages.


h4. Things to keep in mind before you start translating

* Be reasonably sure you understand the source material completely before attempting a translation. It is best to read through the material once before you begin to judge its difficulty; if it seems too high in places, it's best to leave it for another.
* Please leave honorifics in place. This is to keep a consistent style of honorific usage across the board, and Japanese honorifics usually don't translate well to English titles.
* Try not to introduce elements which were not present in the original. Given that Japanese leans on implication and context, sometimes it is unavoidable to make matters explicit in English.
* Don't use Japanese words if an equivalent English term exists.
** But don't go overboard with the above. Some Japanese concepts are untranslatable. If you have to choose between accuracy, understanding, and English, it's better to sacrifice English than understanding or accuracy.
* Make sure your English is idiomatic and well-written. Wooden translations mimicking the Japanese word-for-word are not proper translations. Try to select idioms with the same meanings as Japanese counterparts.
** Limit translation notes to the most intractable jokes, puns, and cultural concepts. It is better for the reader to miss a shade of meaning than be forced to halt and read a note.
** Puns and jokes are a special category on their own. Here it's allowable to be much more flexible, as long as the general meaning remains. It's heaps better to make a joke that clicks in English and then explain nuances in a translation note, than to make something completely unfunny and then explain in a note why it was a joke.
* Endeavor to completely translate the material on an image. That said, if you encounter something you don't understand, it is better to leave it partially translated and put out a call for help.
** When making partial translations, or when continuing on after leaving something untranslated, be reasonably sure the missing context isn't overly detrimental to your understanding.
* Use the names romanized in the same way as our tags have them. Generally this means Surname Forename, and make sure you stick to [[howto:romanize|our romanization rules]] too.
* [b]Ask for help.[/b] Everyone makes mistakes, including native speakers at times. The Japanese language is full of nuances that are sometimes hard to capture in plain text. That being said, try not to translate something out of your understanding -- it is better to have a decent translation improved, than to have a nonsensical translation figured out.

[expand=Translation tasks by difficulty/complexity:]

1. Single words and common phrases
2. Phrases and simple sentence
3. Complex sentences and simple single page comics
4. Simple multipage comics
5. Complex single page comics and paragraphs of text ([[text_focus]] or commentary translation)
6. Complex multipage comics

As a rule of thumb, start small and work your way up. If something feels too difficult or comes out clunky, move to easier tasks until you get the hang of translating
[/expand]

h4. Step by step breakdown of how to translate

* Go to an image in need of translation (look at [[translation_request]]s). You can also try searching the comments for people who "bumped images for translation":[/comments?commit=Search&group_by=comment&search%5Bbody_matches%5D=translation&search%5Border%5D=id_desc&utf8=%E2%9C%93].
* Click on Add Translation in the sidebar to the left or press 'n' on the keyboard. Click and drag on the image around where the text is. One note will be created. (Use multiple notes for multiple parts!)
* To change the size of a note after creating it, move (by dragging) and resize (by dragging the bottom right corner) the note. [b]Remember to save afterwards.[/b] Your changes won't do anything until you save, so it's better to move, then add text than the other way around.
* [b]Try to make the notes as small as possible.[/b] They should obscure the minimal area of the picture. If there are natural borders (such as a rectangular speech box) you can use to hide the note, do it. Make the note match the box pixel-for-pixel as best as you can. Alternatively, stick it as close to the text as possible. (The first frame of post #4487 is a good example of fitting a translation box to text, and post #577456 of fitting it to a box in the image.)
* Hover the mouse cursor inside the note to make an empty square appear below it. Click it to edit.
* Write your translation in the box. Limited HTML markup is allowed; a list of useful tags is available at [[about:note_formatting]]. The site provides several custom named fonts for translation use that are not dependent on browser or OS: see [[about:note_fonts]] for a list. Use <tn>translation note here</tn> to add a translation note. Don't add a linebreak before a translation note, as that's done automatically.
* Repeat until all the text has been translated.
* [b]Make sure you change the [[translation_request]] tag to [[translated]]![/b] 

h4. Tags relating to translation

* [[translation_request]] - images with significant Japanese (or other language, combine with for example [[chinese_text]]) text to translate; that's left completely or partially untranslated.
* [[partially_translated]] - images that have been partially translated. As mentioned above, this isn't generally encouraged, but in some cases it can be fine, such as when the image is very long, or when the text is not strongly related (for example post #570410).
* [[check_translation]] - used for images that have been translated but that either the translator or other people are unsure about whether it's right. Or, perhaps the English is so confusing that the translation needs double-checking to convert it to something that makes sense.
* [[translated]] - images that have been [i]completely[/i] translated. Nothing less than completely (and properly) translated, please. When placing this tag, Remove the [[translation_request]] tag and the [[partially_translated]] if it's there. An image should never be tagged with [[translated]] and [[translation_request]].
* [[hard-translated]] - images that have already gone through [[third-party_edit]] to replace the original text (Japanese or otherwise) with a translation into another different language. It is discouraged on Danbooru.

h4. Translation aids for Danbooru

* "Note assist":[/forum_topics/9373] is a userscript that adds new features to the note system. They include automatically resizing your notes to fit the text as well as buttons for quick access to more advanced note formatting such as text size and color. It is still a work-in-progress and aimed at advanced users.

h4. See also

* [[List of SFX]]

h4. External resources

* Google: Multiple translation options
** https://translate.google.com
** [b]Note:[/b] Straight-up machine translations are not allowed
* WWWJDIC: Japanese -> English
** http://nihongo.monash.edu/cgi-bin/wwwjdic
** http://www.edrdg.org/cgi-bin/wwwjdic/wwwjdic
* DeepL: Japanese -> English
** https://www.deepl.com/translator
** [b]Note:[/b] Straight-up machine translations are not allowed
* The Jaded Network: Japanese SFX
** http://thejadednetwork.com/sfx/search/
* Nihongo Resources: giongo/gitaigo (Japanese SFX) lookup
** http://www.nihongoresources.com/dictionaries/universal.html
** https://github.com/Pomax/nihongoresources.com/blob/master/giongo.txt
* Language Realm: Japanese slang
** http://www.languagerealm.com/japanese/japaneseslang.php
* Jisho: look up words and kanji
** https://jisho.org
** [b]Note:[/b] A modern JMdict/EDICT interface.
* Nihongo Master: expressions/phrases
** https://www.nihongomaster.com/dictionary
* Fuseiji: Helps with figuring out censored words [tn](i.e. when 〇 replaces a character)[/tn]
** http://fuseji.net

title: zektbach
body: Zektbach is a pseudonym of Tomosuke Funaki, who creates many music pieces for the [[Bemani|Beatmania]] and [[Dance Dance Revolution]] series. Zektbach's music contains concepts of fantasy worlds, with which several stories and characters were created. One of those stories is [[Blind Justice]].

title: dino_(pop'n_music)
body: [[Pop'n Music]] character. A [[dinosaur]] who rules the Märchen Kingdom. Close friends of Henry, prince of a neighboring kingdom. Dino loves video games and is a big fan of the [[Bemani|Beatmania]] series. Sometimes he appears with a [[crown]] or a [[wizard hat]].

body:
[[Standing]] in [[water]] more than waist deep, or [[lying]], [[sitting]], or [[kneeling]] in shallow water.

See [[wading]] for characters standing in water less than waist deep.

For objects that are underwater, use [[partially immersed]] instead.

For the camera being partially submerged, see [[partially underwater shot]].

title: tenshou_juuji_hou
body:
Lit. "Heavenly Phoenix Cross"

[[Souther]]'s Nanto Ho-oh Ken ultimate technique. Souther takes a stance with his arms held out evenly, like a cross. As the name suggests, it is launched into a powerful aerial attack. This technique makes the user so light and graceful that he can glide over any physical attack. 

Usually parodied with [[Rumia]] because she takes the exact same pose in [[Embodiment of Scarlet Devil]], and [[Reiuji Utsuho]] because in [[Touhou Hisoutensoku]] she has a similar moveset to Souther in [[Hokuto no Ken: Shinpan no Sousousei Kengou Retsuden]].

h4. See also

* [[Hokuto no Ken]]

title: help:posts
body:
A post represents a single image that's been uploaded. Each post can have many [[help:tags|tags]], [[help:comments|comments]], [[help:notes|notes]], and a single [[help:artist commentary|artist commentary]]. Each post may also belong to multiple [[help:pools|pools]]. If you have an [[help:users|account]], you can also add a post to your [[help:favorites|favorites]] or [[help:favorite groups|favorite groups]].

h4. Searching

Searching for posts is straightforward. Simply enter the tags you want to search for, separating tags by spaces and words [i]within[/i] tags by underscores. For example, searching for {{blonde_hair blue_eyes}} will return every post that has both the [[blonde hair]] tag [b]and[/b] the [[blue eyes]] tag.

Be aware that tags for characters and series are usually known by their original Japanese names, not their English names. For example, the tag on Danbooru for [i]The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya[/i] is [[Suzumiya Haruhi no Yuuutsu]]. See [[help:tags]] for more information.

Danbooru also offers many metatags that let you further refine your search. Metatags allow you to query on things like image width, height, score, uploader, upload date, and more. Consult the [[help:cheatsheet|cheat sheet]] for a complete list of what you can do.

Finally, note that Members are limited to two tags per search. See [[help:users]] for details.

h4. Tag List

In both the post listing page and on individual post pages you'll notice a list of tags with links next to them. Here's an explanation of what the links are:

[b]?[/b]
    This links to the wiki page for the tag. If the tag is an [[help:artists|artist]] type, then you'll be redirected to the artist page.

[b]950[/b]
    The number next to the tag represents how many posts there are. This isn't always the total number of posts for that tag. If you're searching for a combination of tags, this will be the number of posts that have the tag AND the current tag query. If you're not searching for anything, this will be the number of posts found within the last twenty-four hours.

[b]Color[/b]
    Some tag links may be colored green, purple, or red. Green means the tag represents a character. Purple means the tag represents a copyright (things like anime, manga, games, or novels). Red means the tag represents an [[help:artists|artist]].

When you're not searching for a tag, by default the tag list will show the most popular tags within the last three days. When you are searching for tags, the tag list will show related tags, sorted by relevancy.

h2#mode-menu. Mode Menu

[[help:users|Gold and above users]] will notice a menu labeled "Mode" in the sidebar on the main listing page. This menu lets you make several changes without ever leaving the listing page. Simply select an option and whenever you click on a thumbnail, the action will be performed in the background.

[b]View[/b]
    This is the default mode. Whenever you click on a thumbnail, you'll go to that post.

[b]Edit[/b]
    Whenever you click on a thumbnail, an edit box will appear. Here you can easily change the post's tags from the listing page without opening the entire post.

[b]Tag script[/b]
    Write a tag script into the text box that appears, and it will be applied when you click on the thumbnail of a post. This allows you to quickly add or remove tags to many posts at once. See [[help:tag scripts]] for details on creating tag scripts.

[b]Favorite[/b]
    Whenever you click on a thumbnail, that post will be added to your list of [[help:favorites|favorites]].

[b]Unfavorite[/b]
    Whenever you click on a thumbnail, that post will be removed from your list of [[help:favorites|favorites]].

h4. Borders

In the listing page, you will notice that some thumbnails have a border. The meaning of this border depends on the color.

[b]Blue[/b]
    The post is [[about:mod_queue|pending moderator approval]] or was [[about:mod_queue|flagged for deletion]].

[b]Black/Grey[/b]
    The post is [[about:mod_queue|deleted]].

[b]Green[/b]
    The post has [[help:post relationships|child posts]].

[b]Yellow[/b]
    The post has a [[help:post relationships|parent]].

title: evening_gown
body:
An evening gown is a long flowing women's [[dress]] usually worn to a [[formal clothes]] affair. It ranges from mid-calf to full-length, but never above the knees. Evening gowns are often made of a luxury fabric such as chiffon, velvet, satin, or silk. 

If the dress is knee-length of above consider [[cocktail dress]] instead. Evening gowns are formal wear, so they tend to not be extremely revealing, in such cases cocktail dress may be a better tag. 

H4. Examples
* !post #8617606
* !post #6411539
* !post #7323739

h4. See also

* [[cocktail dress]]
* [[gown]]
* [[Tag group:Attire]]
** [[Tag group:Dress]]

* "Wikipedia: Evening gown":[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evening_gown]

title: ace_combat
body:
A popular series of arcade  style flight action games published by [[Bandai Namco]] and developed by in-house team Project Aces. Initially named Air Combat as it’s Namco System 21 arcade original.

From the very first Ace Combat console game, the setting of the games take place in a world similar to Earth but with a radically different history, countries, geography, and having mixed existence of both real and fictional aircraft, as well as exponentially advanced technology, superweapons, submarines, and airships that are larger than life. This world is known as "Strangereal". Two major events have shaped many of the events of the mainline Ace Combat games: The [[ace_combat_zero|Belkan War]], and the [[ace_combat_04|Ulysses Impact]].

The typical Ace Combat plot follows a nameless/faceless fighter pilot's rise from a fledgling rookie to become a feared and respected ace in the war he is fighting, but told in narrative perspective of the people surrounding the pilot. The pilot in question will also typically face off against "rival" aces from the opposing nation. The music in the series has been composed by quite a few talented people within Bandai Namco sound team, with Tetsukazu Nakanishi, Hiroshi Okubo, and Keiki Kobayashi among them. Who also worked on other projects such as [[Tekken]], [[Ridge Racer]], and [[SoulCalibur]].

h4. Games
* Air Combat (1995)
* [[Ace Combat 2]] (1997)
* [[Ace Combat 3]]: Electrosphere (1999)
* [[Ace Combat 04]]: Shattered Skies (2001)
* [[Ace Combat 5]]: The Unsung War (2004)
* [[Ace Combat Zero]]: The Belkan War (2006)
* [[Ace Combat X]]: Skies of Deception (2006)
* [[Ace Combat 6]]: Fires of Liberation (2007)
* [[Ace Combat X2]]: Joint Assault (2010)
* [[Ace Combat Assault Horizon]] (2011)
* [[Ace Combat Infinity]] (2014)
* [[Ace Combat 7]]: Skies Unknown (2019)

h4. External links
* Wikipedia: "Ace Combat":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ace_Combat]

title: nightmare_(kirby)
body:
[quote]
[i]"It was a mistake for you to come here, Kirby. As you can see, you and your puny Star Warriors are no match for me. Challenging me is the last mistake you will ever make."[/i]

-- Nightmare - [i][[kirby: right back at ya!|Combat Kirby]][/i]
[/quote]

Nightmare is a major villain hailing from the [i][[Kirby (series)|]][/i] series of games. He first appears in [[kirby's_adventure|Kirby's Adventure]] as the game's final boss, and he desires to spread [[nightmare|nightmares]] all across Dream Land.

He and Kirby would fight twice.
* !post #5546037: His first form[br] [b] Nightmare's Power Orb [/b] 
* !post #7454736: His second form[br] [b] Nightmare Wizard [/b] 

He also appears in the [[kirby: right back at ya!|anime]] as the main antagonist, where he desires to conquer the universe by selling monsters, usually to someone like [[King Dedede]]. The monsters, along with several other creations, come from his company Nightmare Enterprises.
Voiced by [[Ginga Banjou]].

The villain, as his name suggests, is a living nightmare, and his one and only weakness is the [[Star Rod]].

title: tohsaka_rin_(fate/extra)
body:
A version of [[Tohsaka Rin]] that appears in [[Fate/Extra]], being the Master of [[Cu Chulainn (fate/extra)|]] (since [[Archer (fate)|]] is one of Kishinami Hakuno's playable Servants). [spoilers]She is a distant relative of FSN Rin's, and her hair is actually blonde due to her avatar being tweaked to make it black[/spoilers]. She can be distinguished from the [[Fate/stay night]] version by the red trim on her hair bows.

Depending on the game this Rin appears in, her outfit varies:

* [[Fate/Extra]]: swaps out thighhighs for [[black footwear|black]] [[thigh boots]] that have thigh straps, and her [[red shirt]] has gloves on the ends (post #588235). This outfit is additionally adapted for the [b]Code Cast[/b] [[Craft Essence (fate)|]] (post #3254593).
** She also wears a second costume [spoilers]when she is revealed to be blonde in real life[/spoilers], where she wears skin-tight [[black pants]] which reveals her [[butt crack]], and a see-through [[black capelet]] (post #2170955).
* [[Fate/Extra CCC]]: may be seen wearing the [[Tsukumihara Academy Uniform (fate/extra ccc)|]].
* [[Fate/Extra Record]]: wears a black leotard-esque shirt, [[red skirt]], and black thigh boots (post #4019196).
* [[Fate/Extra Last Encore]]: becomes a [[tohsaka rin (lancer)|Lancer-class Demi-Servant]] fused with Cu Chulainn's Spirit Origin.

title: pedestrian_push_button
body:
A button pedestrians should push when waiting at a [[crosswalk]] to activate its [[pedestrian lights]].

Due to many pedestrian lights being automatically tied to the traffic lights, pedestrian push buttons are frequently a placebo button that does nothing.

title: shingou-ax
body:
[[Battle axe]] from “[[Kamen Rider Drive (series)|]]”. It is modeled after a [[pedestrian lights]].
The main user is [[Kamen Rider Chaser]], but other [[Kamen Rider Drive]] and [[Kamen Rider Mach]] / [[Shijima Gou]] also used it.
When the [[pedestrian push button]] is pushed, it starts charging energy, and when the charge is complete, it says “Itte iiyo!” (You may proceed) is sounded when the charge is complete. In this state, pushing the trigger at the bottom of the handle activates the “[b]Across Breaker[/b],” a special move that cleaves the enemy.

title: kamen_rider_drive
body:
Lead Rider of [[kamen_rider_drive_(series)|Kamen Rider Drive]], twenty-fifth show in the Kamen Rider series and sixteenth of the Heisei generation.

[[Tomari Shinnosuke]] was an ace police detective demoted to a special investigations division due to dismotivation following an incident where one of his colleagues was crippled. When his new team was assigned to look after cases of people suddenly becoming immobile, however, Shinnosuke was given a chance to reignite his passion with the super-car Tridoron and its sentient belt to transform into Kamen Rider Drive and fight the Roidmudes, monsters connected to the freezing incidents.

In a departure from series tradition, Drive is the first Rider to primarily use a car for transportation, and uses Shift Cars to either change his appearance and/or arsenal.

title: super_robot_wars_dd
body:
A [[Super Robot Wars]] title released for smartphones in 2019. While all units are unlocked through story progression, it features gacha elements for attack equipment. The game released with 4 worlds, each featuring a different set of series, while more worlds with new series are added periodically.

It has made SRW history by featuring the series' first instances of cross-series pilot swapping. In order, the Crossing Pilot events are as follows:
* [[Char's Counterattack]] x [[Mazinger Z]] - [[Amuro Ray]] pilots [[Mazinger Z (mecha)|]].
* [[Code Geass]] x [[Gundam Wing: Endless Waltz]] - [[Lelouch Vi Britannia]] pilots [[Wing Gundam Zero Rebellion]].
* [[Super Robot Wars Original Generation]] x [[Seisenshi Dunbine]] - [[Masaki Andoh]] pilots [[Billbine]].
* [[Full Metal Panic!]] x [[Choudenji Machine Voltes V]] - [[Sagara Sousuke]] pilots [[Voltes V (mecha)|]].
* [[Aoki Ryuusei SPT Layzner]] x [[Soukou Kihei VOTOMS]] - [[Asuka Eiji]] pilots a [[Scopedog eiji custom|custom Scopedog]].

title: nazono_mito
body:
The [[animegao]] [[kigurumi]] version of [[Nijisanji]]'s [[Tsukino Mito]], revealed on her 2019 April Fools "stream":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P8WTrOlMhVk. Later nicknamed Nazono Mito (lit. Mysterious Rabbit) by fans, the mysterious figure appeared in full Tsukino Mito cosplay (including an [[animegao]] mask and zentai bodysuit).

The stream and the bizarre character were very popular among fans to the point that Nazono Mito became a recurring character on Tsukino Mito's channel, in her music, and even at real life events.

title: leon_(blade_runner)
body:
A character from the 80s [[cyberpunk]] science fiction movie [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]]. He was played by the late American actor "Brion James":http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brion_James.

[b]Leon Kowalski[/b] is a member of [[Roy Batty]]'s band of fugitive [[replicant]]s in the film. Leon has an A Physical Level (superhuman strength and endurance) & a C Mental Level (subnormal intelligence). 

He is often brutal and sadistic in his methods but not very smart, even for human standards. Because of this Leon tends to resort to raw savagery and violence when trapped in a difficult and stressing situation he can't control. 

His model number is NEXUS-6 N6MAC41717.
other_names: リオン・コワルスキー

title: blade_runner_2049
body:
A 2017 American [[science fiction]] [[cyberpunk]] film directed by Denis Villeneuve and produced by Ridley Scott.

A sequel to the 1982 cult film [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]], the film stars [[Ryan Gosling]] and [[Harrison Ford]], with [[Ana de Armas]], [[Dave Bautista]] and [[Jared Leto]] in supporting roles.

Three short films have been made to explore events that occur in the 30-year period between Blade Runner and Blade Runner 2049: 

* [[Blade Runner: Black Out 2022]] (anime)
* "2036: Nexus Dawn":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UgsS3nhRRzQ (live action)
* "2048: Nowhere to Run":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aZ9Os8cP_gg (live action)

h4. Characters

* [[K (Blade Runner 2049)|]]
* [[Joi]]
* [[Sapper Morton]]

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Blade Runner 2049":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blade_Runner_2049

title: pris
body:
A character from the 80s [[cyberpunk]] science fiction film [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]] played by actress [[Daryl Hannah]].

[b]Pris[/b] is a member of [[Roy Batty]]'s band of fugitive replicants in the film. 

Pris is a "pleasure model" [[replicant]] created for entertainment and thus even more of a slave-object than the others. She has an A Physical level (superhuman strength and endurance), but her B Mental Level (standard intelligence) puts her at a lower intellectual level than Roy. 

Pris was incepted (developed) on [[valentine|Valentine's day]].  

Her model number is NEXUS-6 N6FAB21416.
other_names: プリス・ストラットン

title: eldon_tyrell
body:
A character from the 80s science fiction film, [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]]. He is played by American actor "Joe Turkel":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Turkel].

[b]Dr. Eldon Tyrell[/b] is the biomechanics genius who founded (and owns) the large and powerful Tyrell Corporation. His most famous creations are the organic androids known as [[replicant]]s.

title: gillian_seed
body:
A character from the [[Snatcher]] [[cyberpunk]] science fiction [[video game]] from the 80s.

[b]Gillian Seed[/b] is a detective who is assigned to investigate a breed of [[android]]s known as [[Snatcher (robot)|]]s, who are killing humans and taking their place in society.

The character was inspired and based on [[Rick Deckard]] from the movie [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]].

"Alternate pixiv query":http://www.pixiv.net/search.php?s_mode=s_tag&word=%E3%82%AE%E3%83%AA%E3%82%A2%E3%83%B3%20%E3%82%B9%E3%83%8A%E3%83%83%E3%83%81%E3%83%A3%E3%83%BC

* [[Jamie Seed]]

title: rachel_(blade_runner)
body:
[b]Rachel[/b], also known as [b]Rachael[/b] or [b]Rachael Tyrell[/b], is a character from the science fiction film [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]], played by actress [[Sean Young]].

She is [spoiler]a Nexus 7 [[replicant]] with B physical and mental levels (regular human type) that was also given the ability to reproduce and a normal person's lifespan. Her serial number is NEXUS-7 N7FAA52318. Rachael also appears in the sequel [[Blade Runner 2049]].[/spoiler]

title: snatcher
body:
[b]Snatcher[/b] (スナッチャー [i]Sunacchā[/i]) is a [[cyberpunk]] graphic adventure [[video game]] produced by [[Konami]], originally released in Japan for the NEC PC-8801 and MSX 2 computer platforms in 1988. 

It was followed by a CD-ROM remake released for the [[PC Engine]] video game console in 1992, which was subsequently ported and localized into English for the Mega-CD/[[Sega CD]] in 1994. 

Snatcher was the second video game written and directed by [[Kojima Hideo]], following the original [[metal_gear_(series)|Metal Gear]] for the MSX2. 

The game's futuristic story centers around a detective called [[Gillian Seed]], who is assigned to investigate a breed of [[android]]s known as "Snatchers", who are killing humans and taking their place in society. The game is known for its heavy influence from cult [[science fiction]] films such as [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]], [[Akira (manga)|]] and [[The Terminator]].

h4. See also

* [[Snatcher (robot)]]
* [[Gillian Seed]]
* [[Jamie Seed]] 
* [[Metal Gear Mk. II]]
* [[Mika Slayton]]
* [[Benson Cunningham]]
* [[Harry Benson]]
* [[Jean Jack Gibson]]
* [[Katrina Gibson]]
* [[Random Hajile]]

title: random_hajile
body:
A character from the [[Snatcher]] [[cyberpunk]] science fiction [[video game]] from the 80s.

[b]Random Hajile[/b] is a [[bounty hunter]] who has [[blonde_hair|blonde]] [[spiked hair]] and wears a dark motorcycle outfit. His weapon of choice is a [[sawed-off shotgun]]. 

Random usually travels riding a futuristic [[unicycle]].

The character's look was based in both [[Roy Batty]] from [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]] and [[Feyd-Rautha]] from [[dune (series)|Dune]].

title: bubblegum_crisis
body:
[b][i]Bubblegum Crisis[/i][/b] (バブルガムクライシス, [i]Baburugamu Kuraishisu[/i]) is a [[cyberpunk]] [[mecha]] anime OVA set in a future, post-earthquake Tokyo, called "Mega Tokyo". It was released in 1987.

The series displays strong influences from [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]], also making occasional references to it.

A TV series remake, [[Bubblegum Crisis 2040|Bubblegum Crisis Tokyo 2040]], was broadcast in 1998.

h4. See also

* [[Parasite Dolls]]

title: zhora
body:
A character from the 80s [[cyberpunk]] science fiction movie [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]]. She is played by American actress "Joanna Cassidy":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joanna_Cassidy .

[b]Zhora[/b], a [[replicant]], has an A Physical Level (superhuman strength and endurance) & a B Mental Level (normal intelligence). She has been trained in political homicide (i.e. assassination). 

Zhora is a member of [[Roy Batty]]'s band of fugitives. She managed to get a job as an exotic dancer at Taffey's Bar in the film. 

Her model number is NEXUS-6 N6FAB61216.

title: roy_batty
body:
A character from the 80s [[cyberpunk]] science fiction movie [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]]. He is the main antagonist in the film and was played by actor [[Rutger Hauer]].

[b]Roy Batty[/b] is the leader of the renegade Nexus-6 [[replicant]]s. He is very intelligent, strong, resilient, fast, and skilled at combat, and yet still learning how to deal with developing emotions. 

With an A Physical Level (superhuman strength & endurance) and an A Mental Level (genius level intellect), he is probably the most dangerous of all the fugitive replicants. 

He is an specialized combat model, used off-world for [[military]] service, and is said to have participated in every off-world battle and conflict from the fighting at the Tannhauser Gate to the Massacre on the Venezeualan Moons.

Roy leads a few fellow replicants in the hope of self-preservation during the film. 

His model number is NEXUS-6 N6MAA10816.

title: hannibal_chew
body:
A character from the 80s science fiction film, [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]]. He is played by Asian-American actor "James Hong":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Hong .

[b]Hannibal Chew[/b] is an excentric Asian bio-engineer expert at developing [[replicant]] eyes.

title: gaff_(blade_runner)
body:
One of the main characters from the 80s [[Science Fiction]] film, [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]]. He is played by actor [[Edward James Olmos]].

[b]Gaff[/b] is a veteran, silent and enigmatic Blade Runner who always dresses formaly and wears a hat. He walks with a cane and a noticeable limp. 

Gaff often communicates in a strange street lingo called "Cityspeak" that is a mixture of Japanese, Spanish, German, English and many other languages.

title: blade_runner:_black_out_2022
body:
[i][b]Blade Runner: Black Out 2022[/b][/i] is a neo-noir [[science fiction]] [[cyberpunk]] anime short film directed by Watanabe Shinichiro (of [[Cowboy Bebop]] fame), with concept art and background designs by [[paooo|Paul Chadeisson]]. 

The plot takes place 3 years after the events of [[Blade Runner (1982 movie)|]] (1982).

Black Out 2022 is one of three short films, alongside [i][b]"2036: Nexus Dawn":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UgsS3nhRRzQ [/b][/i] and [i][b]"2048: Nowhere to Run":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aZ9Os8cP_gg [/b][/i], that serve as prequels to the live-action film [[Blade Runner 2049]]. 

The anime short has a duration of 15 minutes and debuted on 27 September 2017 on Crunchyroll. It is currently available for free viewing in YouTube.

h4. Characters

* [[Trixie (blade runner)|]]

h4. External links

* "Official release in YouTube by Warner Bros Pictures":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rrZk9sSgRyQ (English)
* "Wikipedia: Blade Runner Black Out 2022":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blade_Runner_Black_Out_2022

title: replicant
body:
Organic [[android]]s that first appeared in the [[cyberpunk]] science fiction movie [[Blade Runner (series)|]].

The [b]Replicants[/b] are genetically engineered artificial human clones used for slave labor in the off-world colonies. They can be designed with different levels of intelligence and strength (according to their use), from standard human or subhuman levels to superhuman and genius type.

They have short life-spans and are banned on Earth.

title: the_man_in_the_high_castle
body:
[b]The Man in the High Castle[/b] is an American multimedia [[alternate universe|alternate history]] franchise where the Axis powers [[Nazi]] [[Germany]] and the Empire of [[Japan]] rule the world after their [[World War II]] [[victory]]. Both Germany and Japan divided and occupied the [[United States]], and were later involved in a tense [[Cold War]] fighting for supremacy over the new world order.

The series is based in a 1962 novel by [[Philip K. Dick]], creator of [[Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?]] ([[Blade Runner (series)|]]).

h4. See also

* [[Kerberos Saga]]
* [[Wolfenstein (series)|]]

title: rick_deckard
body:
One of the main characters from the 80s [[science fiction]] film, [[Blade Runner (series)|]]. He also appears in the novel [[Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?]], on which the movie was partially based.

[b]Rick Deckard[/b] is the protagonist of the film and the narrator in the original cinematic release. He is played by [[Harrison Ford]].

Deckard is a "Blade Runner", a special [[detective]] in the Los Angeles [[police]] department employed to hunt down and "[[murder|retire]]" [[replicant]]s in the year 2019. 

Deckard's weapon of choice is the [[PKD Blaster]]. His ID number is B-2-63-54.

[spoiler]By the end of the film it's ambiguous as to whether he's a replicant himself or not.[/spoiler]

title: blade_runner_(1982_movie)
body:
A 1982 American [[science fiction]] film, directed by Ridley Scott and starring [[Harrison Ford]], [[Rutger Hauer]], [[Edward James Olmos]], [[Daryl Hannah]] and [[Sean Young]].

The screenplay, written by Hampton Fancher and David Peoples, is loosely based on the 1968 novel [[Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?]] by American sci-fi writer [[Philip K. Dick]].

While not initially a success with North American audiences, [i][b]Blade Runner[/b][/i] was very popular internationally and became a cult film. It was a hit in Japan, where it greatly influenced the "[[cyberpunk]]" look of later sci-fi anime and manga like [[Akira (manga)|]], [[Bubblegum Crisis]], [[Armitage III]], [[Ghost in the Shell]] and [[Appleseed]] among many many others. 

The movie's dark style and futuristic designs by [[Syd Mead]] have served as a benchmark and its influence can be seen in many subsequent science fiction films, anime, video games, and television programs.

A sequel called [[Blade Runner 2049]] was released in most countries on October 6, 2017. It was released in Japan on October 27, 2017.

title: street_fighter_iv_(series)
body: The fifth mainline [[Street Fighter]] fighting game series, first released in 2008. It was the first mainline games to features 3D graphics (as [[Street Fighter EX (series)|]] is considered non-canon spin-off). The game is set between [[Street Fighter II (series)|]] and [[Street Fighter III (series)|III]].

title: street_fighter_ii_(series)
body:
The second [[Street Fighter]] game released by [[Capcom]] in 1991.

The game is a drastic improvement over [[Street Fighter I|the first game]], featuring larger cast of playable fighters along with pioneering various mechanics that became a staple of the fighting games today. It still remains one of the most popular game of the series, both for casual and competitive scene.

title: street_fighter_iii_(series)
body:
The fourth main installment of the [[Street Fighter]] franchise, released in 1997 as a direct sequel to [[Street Fighter II (series)|]] (as opposed to the earlier [[street fighter zero (series)|Zero/Alpha]] series that acts as a prequel to SFII).

Intended to introduce a "new generation" of fighters, Street Fighter III discarded the character roster from previous games, with only [[Ryu (street fighter)|]] and [[Ken Masters|Ken]] returned, introducing several new characters in their place, most notably the female ninja [[Ibuki (street fighter)|]], twin brothers [[Yun Lee|Yun]] and [[Yang Lee|Yang]], and grappler [[Alex (street fighter)|]]. Street Fighter III introduced the Super Arts selection system and the ability to parry an opponent's attack.

Capcom would later introduce two updates to the game - [i]Second Impact[/i] in 1998, which introduced two new characters as well as bringing back [[Akuma (street fighter)|]], and [i]3rd Strike[/i] in 1999, which introduced 4 new characters and brought back [[Chun-Li]].

The series was initially marked as the latest chronologically in the Street Fighter timeline for 26 years (as [[Street Fighter IV (series)|]] and [[Street Fighter V]] were set between SFII and III) until the release of [[Street Fighter 6]] in 2023.

h4. Introduced in New Generation

title: virgin_destroyer_sweater
body:
A [[meme attire|meme outfit]] originally created by [[Dishwasher1910]] reminiscent of the [[virgin killer sweater]] except with [[detached sleeves]] and the front-covering portion below the chest splits off into straps resembling [[garter straps]] that connect to sweater [[thighhighs]]. A [[thong]] of the same color is usually worn with the outfit.

h4. Original design

* !post #6168993: by [[Dishwasher1910]] created in 2021

It gained a sudden boom in popularity in December 2023 due to an art challenge among [[hololive]] fanbases in anticipation of that year's [[Christmas]].

title: ravio
body:
A character from [i][[The Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds]][/i].  He runs Ravio's Shop, from which [[Link]] can either rent or purchase items essential to his quest. That's male in long purple tunic, bunny headwear, blue-black [[striped scarf]] and [[brown boots]].

[spoiler]He is the counterpart of Link in Lorule, a parallel version of Hyrule. He looks like a negative version of [[Link]]. He's a [[black hair]]ed male with [[pointy ears]] who wears [[purple hat]], blue-black [[striped scarf]], [[brown boots]], [[white pants]] and [[purple tunic]] with [[short over long sleeves|short over long black sleeves]] and [[belt]] on them.
[/spoiler]

title: ayanami_(azur_lane)
body:
[[Azur Lane]]'s personification of the Japanese destroyer [i]Ayanami[/i]. Character design by [[Ootsuki Momiji]], voiced by [[Taichi You]]. 

She is a Japanese/Korean/Taiwan server-only starter ship, being replaced by [[Z23 (azur lane)|]] in the English and Mainland Chinese servers. She is claimable after obtaining the other three starters.

She has light gray/[[blonde hair]], [[orange eyes|orange]] or [[red eyes]], and initially wears a modified [[serafuku|schoolgirl uniform]] and [[rudder footwear|rudder boots]], before her remodel switches her to an outfit with miko sleeves, a [[miniskirt]], loafer-type rudder footwear, and [[zettai ryouiki]]. Her clothes are short enough to expose her [[midriff]], and, in her retrofit, a fair amount of [[underboob]] as well.

Her [[rigging]] consists of a single 12.7 cm twin gun mount Type B to her left, a funnel-mast backpack on her back, a [[searchlight]] strapped to her belt on the left, and two 61 cm triple [[torpedo tubes]]. Upon retrofit, her searchlight and gun mount are remounted to the funnel backpack.

Bondrewd is a tall man often seen wearing a black [[overcoat]], a [[black suit]] and a black [[helm]]. His signature pose is the [[subarashii pose]], due to his tendency to strike this peculiar stance whenever he finds something interesting.

title: ford
body:
A manufacturer of motor vehicles based in the [[United States|United States of America]]. It was founded by [[Henry Ford]] on June 16, 1903.

Ford is the parent company of [[Lincoln (company)|]], and retains their trademarks for the now-defunct [[Mercury (company)|]] brand. They also previously owned several still-active foreign car brands, namely [[Volvo]], [[Mazda]], [[Aston Martin]], [[Jaguar (car)|]], and [[Land Rover (Company)|]].

title: land_rover_range_rover
body: Range Rover is a 4x4 [[sports utility vehicle|SUV]] produced by [[Land Rover (Company)|]]. The Range Rover line was launched in 1970 by British Leyland. The original Range Rover was not designed as a luxury vehicle, but with the evolution of the 5th generation models, the Range Rover has become a representative of luxury SUVs.

title: the_end_(sonic_frontiers)
body:
The final boss of [[Sonic Frontiers]]. The End is the being responsible of destroying the Ancients' home planet, forcing them to flee towards Earth. After it followed them, the Ancients built four Titans to fight it, then seal it inside Cyber Space, a digital dimension. Many ages later, it tricks [[sonic_the_hedgehog|Sonic]] into liberating it once again, corrupting him in the process.

The End appears before [[Super Sonic]] and [[sage_(sonic)|Sage]] as a [[purple moon|purple]] [[moon]]. On Easy and Normal difficulties, the fight takes place in a quick-time event. On Hard difficulty, Sage must first face it in a shooting section while piloting [[supreme_(sonic_frontiers)|Supreme]].

In the game's Another Story campaign, added in [[sonic frontiers: the final horizon|The Final Horizon]] update, The End will instead take control of Supreme and use it to fight Sonic, who uses the power unlocked from his corruption to grant his transformation a power boost and destroy it.

title: supreme_(sonic_frontiers)
body:
The fourth and last Titan faced by [[Super Sonic]] in [[Sonic Frontiers]]. A large, humanoid entity that wields an [[arm cannon]]. It has a predominantly white and red color scheme, unlike the other Titans' black and grey.

After the battle, Supreme is operated by [[sage_(sonic)|Sage]] to aid [[sonic_the_hedgehog|Sonic]] on a last stand against [[the_end_(sonic_frontiers)|The End]], a creature weakened and sealed by the Titans ages ago.

In the game's Another Story campaign, added in [[sonic frontiers: the final horizon|The Final Horizon]] update, instead of fighting alone, the End will connect itself to the Titan, making it grow [[extra arms]] and walk on all fours. [[Super Sonic 2|Super Sonic]] must then sever their connection and use his corruption's power to destroy them.

title: sonic_frontiers:_the_final_horizon
body: Third and final DLC for [[Sonic Frontiers]], which is a major expansion featuring Another Story, an alternate take on Chronos Island segment and its storyline.

title: barrett_m99
body: The Barrett M99 (Model 99) is a single-shot [[anti-materiel rifle]] chambered in .50 BMG (12.7×99mm), the gun was first introduced in 1999 by the Barrett Firearms Company as a less expensive alternative to the company's higher-priced offerings. The [[rifle]] uses a [[bullpup]] configuration with a pistol grip.

title: barrett_m95
body: The Barrett M95 is a [[bullpup]] bolt-action [[anti-materiel rifle]] chambered in .50 BMG (12.7×99mm), and manufactured by Barrett Firearms Company. It has been adopted by a number of militaries around the world.

title: yui_shousetsu_(exhibition_attire)_(fate)
body:
[quote]祝・「Fate/Grand Order」九周年！！

記念すべき日の祭典であなたを迎えるのは
普段と装いを変えた英霊たち。

今までの冒険を形に留めて、
今日は目いっぱい盛り上がろう。[/quote]

title: civil_war_(2024)
body: [b]Civil War[/b] is a 2024 dystopian action thriller movie directed by Alex Garland. The movie follows a group of war journalists during a civil war in the United States between the despotic US government and Secessionist movements.

title: gewehr_41
body:
A [[World War II]]-era German semi-automatic [b][[rifle]][/b] chambered for 7.92×57mm Mauser [[rifle cartridge|cartridge]], designed in 1941. It was the predecessor of the [[Gewehr 43]]. 
The Gewehr 41 resembles a [[mauser 98|Kar98k]] with a 10-round [[magazine (weapon)|]], two handguard bands, and a [b]straight[/b] bolt handle instead of bent one. 

h1. See also 
* [[List of weapons]]
* [[SVT-38]]
* [[SVT-40]]

H1. External links
* "Wikipedia: Gewehr 41":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gewehr_41

title: i_am_your_father_(meme)
body:
[quote][i]"NO...!!! I AM YOUR FATHER...!!!"[/i] - Darth Vader to Luke Skywalker in [i]The Empire Strikes Back[/i][/quote]

A [[meme]] originated from the most famous scene in [[Star Wars]]: [[star wars: the empire strikes back|The Empire Strikes Back]].

The scene revolves [[Darth Vader]] and [[Luke Skywalker]] fighting with their [[lightsaber]]s, when Vader manages to cut off Luke's right hand and forced him to the corner. Vader then revealed that he is, in fact, [[Anakin Skywalker|his father]] whom Luke was told that had died long time ago. This culminated into Luke screaming and crying out of disbelief, anguish and agony.

Contrary to popular belief, Vader never says the name Luke during his quote.

title: storm_border
body:
A vehicle utilized by [[Novum Chaldea]] in [[Fate/Grand Order]]. It was constructed during the [[Atlantis (fate/grand order)|]] Lostbelt using the [[Shadow Border]] and the remains of the [[Nautilus (fate)|]] as a basis. It is capable of traveling through both water and air, and can detach the Shadow Border for independent travel as a land vehicle.

h4. External links
* "Type-Moon Wiki":https://typemoon.fandom.com/wiki/Storm_Border

body:
A playable [[Honkai Impact 3rd]]/[[Benghuai Xueyuan]] character. The true Second Herrscher/Herrscher of the Void, voiced by [[Tange Sakura]] in Japanese. 

She is portrayed with [[long hair|long]] [[purple hair]], [[yellow eyes]] with [[diamond-shaped pupils]], and [[medium breasts]]. Her default outfit consists of a dark [[purple dress]] worn over a [[white dress|white]] layer and a [[center opening]], [[coattails]], [[purple gloves|purple]] [[elbow gloves]], [[leg wrap]]s for her ankles and feet, and a single purple crystal [[anklet]]. 

Not to be confused with [[kiana_kaslana_(herrscher_of_the_void)|Void Kiana]] as her soul was split in half (with [[Kiana Kaslana (white comet)|K-423 Kiana]] receiving the more benevolent traits).

* !post #6287048: Default (BH)

title: sanbaka_(nijisanji)
body:
An official [[Nijisanji]] trio that debuted on March 22, 2019. Although the name is a contraction of the term [i]Samba Carnival[/i], their shenanigans as a trio led to the name's more well-known second meaning: [i]The Three Idiots[/i], a literal reading of the term.

[u]Use this tag when:[/u]
* The image mentions the name "Sanbaka / さんばか / 3bk".
* All three of the members are grouped together. May also include [[Sebastian Piyodore]], [[BanKen (Inui Toko)|]], and/or [[Mandragora (Ange Katrina)|]]. 

h4. Members

* !post #3455079: [[Ange Katrina]]
* !post #3455067: [[Inui Toko]]
* !post #4582668: [[Lize Helesta]]

h4. See also

* [[Sanbaka Anniversary Outfit]] - The matching [[idol clothes|idol]] outfit given to all 3 members to commemorate their 3rd anniversary
* [[Page of Lambda]] - An official alternate universe setting starring Sanbaka.

title: neon_palette
body:
A palette predominated by bright, saturated, [[shiny]] and even [[glowing]] colors with an overall cool tone. [[pink theme|Pink]], [[purple theme|purple]], [[blue theme|blue]] and [[aqua theme|aqua]] are the most common and iconic colors, but other colors such as red, green and yellow may be used as well.

Often associated with electronic, digital and mild futuristic themes such as [[arcade]], [[cyberpunk]], [[cityscape]], [[city lights]], [[vaporwave]], [[video game]]s, [[glitch]]es, [[nightclub]]s and their [[bar (place)|]]s, certain types of [[concert]]s etc.

h4. See also

* [[colorful]]
* [[iridescent]]
* [[holographic clothing]]

* [[neon lights]]
* [[neon trim]]

title: meiji
body:
The [b]Meiji era[/b] (明治時代 [i]Meiji jidai[/i], lit. "Age of Enlightened Rule") is the official name of the era of Japanese history spanning from October 23th, 1868, to July 30th, 1912.

Coinciding the succession of [[emperor mutsuhito|Emperor Meiji]] in 1867, the [[edo jidai|Tokugawa Shogunate]] was being pressured to modernize Japan, an idea the Emperor was sympathetic towards. With political support, the shogunate would come to its official end and Imperial power would be restored, remembered as the Meiji Restoration. Shortly thereafter, the [[Boshin War]] began in 1868, and later that year, Edo was renamed to Tokyo, the Emperor was crowned in October, and officially the [i]Keiō[/i] era was formally changed to the Meiji era. The Boshin War ended in Imperial victory in 1869.

It was a time of hasty modernization and westernization, as Japan transitioned from being a feudal society to an emergent regional great power by Western standards. It was followed up by the [[Taishou]] era.

h4. See also

* [[Meiji schoolgirl uniform]]

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Meiji era":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meiji_era

title: taishou
body:
The [b]Taishou era[/b] (大正時代 [i]Taishō jidai[/i], lit. "Age of Great Righteousness") is the official name of the era of Japanese history spanning from July 30th, 1912, to December 25th, 1926.

Coinciding with the reign of Emperor Taishō, it was a time of political change in Japan towards democracy and liberalism, distinguished from the hasty modernization and westernization of the preceding [[Meiji]] era, and the rise and domination of ultra-nationalistic militarism of the early [[Shouwa]] era. 

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Taishō":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taish%C5%8D

title: reiwa
body:
The [b]Reiwa era[/b] (令和時代 [i]Reiwa jidai[/i], lit. "Age of Sacred Peace") is the official name of the present era of Japanese history, which began on May 1, 2019 following the abdication of [[Emperor Akihito]] and the ascension of Crown Prince [[Emperor Naruhito|Naruhito]] to the Chrysanthemum Throne.

The Reiwa era follows the [[Heisei]] era (1989-2019), the [[Shouwa]] era (1926-1989), the [[Taishou]] era (1912-1926), and the [[Meiji]] era (1868-1912). Since the Meiji era, each era has corresponded to the rule of one emperor.

The name of the new era was announced during a press conference in which Chief Cabinet Secretary [[Suga Yoshihide]] [[holding sign|held up a sign]] revealing the new name. This event has revived a minor [[meme]], with many posts parodying the reveal of the new name in a fashion that had been done periodically with Suga's predecessor, [[Obuchi Keizou]].

h4. External links

* "The Japan Times: Japan reveals name of new era ahead of Emperor's abdication":https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2019/04/01/national/politics-diplomacy/japan-readies-announce-name-new-era/
* "Wikipedia: Reiwa period":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiwa_period
* "Wikimedia Commons: Yoshihide Suga announcing new imperial era Reiwa":[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Yoshihide_Suga_announcing_new_imperial_era_Reiwa_2_(cropped).jpg]
* "Youtube: Official live stream of the announcement":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mt40RYc7znc&t=28m23s

title: shouwa
body:
The Shouwa era is an Imperial period of Japanese history following [[Taishou]] spanning from 1926, December 25th, with the ascension to [[Emperor Hirohito|Emperor Shōwa]], to 1989, January 7th, ending with his death. It was a long era spanning the majority of the 20th Century and generally divided into periods before and after the end of [[World War II ]] and the subsequent occupation era.

The first half was defined by militaristic Imperial Japan's involvement in several wars, especially the two World Wars.

The second, post-war age is when restored democratic Japan became an economic power and the era ended with Japan in the midst of an economic bubble. When the Japanese say something is Shouwa-like and nostalgic, they usually mean something from the [[1980s (style)|]], [[1970s (style)|]], or possibly [[1960s (style)|]].

It was succeeded by the [[Heisei]] era.

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Shōwa era":[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shōwa_era]

title: heisei
body:
[b]Heisei[/b] (平成, lit. "becoming peaceful" or "peace everywhere") is the official name of the era of Japanese history spanning from 1989 to 2019.

Beginning immediately after the death of [[Emperor Hirohito]] and the ascension of Crown Prince [[Emperor Akihito|Akihito]] to the Chrysanthemum Throne, the Heisei era followed the [[Shouwa]] era (1926-1989), the [[Taishou]] era (1912-1926), and the [[Meiji]] era (1868-1912). The Heisei ended on May 1, 2019, when Akihito abdicated and his son [[Emperor Naruhito|Naruhito]] succeeded him as emperor, marking the beginning of the [[Reiwa]].

h4. See also

* [[Heisei Retro]]

h4. External links

* "Wikipedia: Heisei period":https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heisei_period

title: 114514_(meme)
body:
A popular meme from [[Manatsu No Yo No Inmu]] that made its way to [[Cookie (touhou)|]] as well.  

From comment #2010702:
Like all numbers in this picture, it's Japanese number code.
1 = i(chi)
4 = shi/yo
5 = go/ko

So it can be translated as 'iiyo, koi yo' or 'all right, cum!'

Other related numbers that sometimes appear as well:
1919: Saying each number invidually becomes "i ku i ku", which sounds like "cum, cum"
810: Can be split into "8 10", then translated as "ya ju", for [[Yajuu Senpai]]
3777: Sa(n) na(na) na(na) na(na) = [[Sananana (cookie)|]]
364364: 見ろよ、見ろよ, said by [[Miura Daisenpai]]

title: stacked_clothes_dryer
body:
A style of [[clothes dryer]] designed to save space by either being stacked atop or built atop another clothes dryer or a [[washing machine]]. Units composed of two dryers stacked one on the other is a common feature of [[laundromat]]s.  For homes with limited space a dryer unit atop a washing machine, known as a laundry center or laundry tower, is also common.

Washing machines normally aren't stacked due to the additional weight and force of the moving water while in operation and are always the bottom unit of a laundry tower or stacked washer and dryer pair.

h4. Examples

* !post #7564553: A dryer atop a washing machine
* !post #8905979: Stacked dryers at a laundromat

title: hidamari_sketch
body:
A Japanese [[4koma]] series by [[Aoki Ume]] revolving around the daily lives of a group of young girls all living in the same apartment where artists gather.

A 12 episode anime adaptation by [[Shaft (company)|]] aired in Spring 2007. It was followed by three sequel series, in 2008, 2010, and 2012.

The manga was licensed in North America as [i]Sunshine Sketch[/i].

title: drill_instructor
body:
A [b]Drill Instructor[/b] is the person in charge of seeing new recruits to the [[military]] through boot camp. Almost always holding the [[military rank insignia|rank or rate]] of a non-commissioned officer, the instructors' duties include imparting discipline and military bearing, ensuring recruits meet basic standards for fitness, marksmanship, and other metrics, and preparing recruits for their next stages of training and combat roles. 

The most famous example in media is without question [[United States Marine Corps]] [[sgt hartman|Gunnery Sergeant Hartman]] from the movie [[Full Metal Jacket]], which is also the reasoning behind the naming of this tag, as the term "Drill Instructor" is almost exclusively used by the USMC. Most other services and nationalities use the term "Drill [b]Sergeant[/b]" or other variations, but they all are applicable under this tag.

title: banken_(inui_toko)
body:
A pair of [[dog]]-like companions and mascots of [[Nijisanji]]'s [[Inui Toko]].

The vast majority of the time they take the form of Inui's [[animal hair ornament]]s. Use this tag only when they appear in some other way.

They are individually named Ban and Ken but are identical in appearance, except in [[Page of Lambda]] where they appear as twin [[dog girl]]s with different hairstyles — for those versions see [[Ban (Page of Lambda)]] and [[Ken (Page of Lambda)]].

title: mermaid_out_of_environment
body:
A [[mermaid]] or [[merman]] not in their typical environment (typical environments being [[ocean|the sea]], [[beach]], [[lake]], [[river]]). Common uses for this tag can be for mermaids in [[pool]]s or [[bathtub]]s, but generally can be used for mermaids in scenery you wouldn't typically find them in. 

Backgrounds with limited features such as [[simple background]]s do not count towards this tag unless the character is interacting with a non-sea related object such a [[bed sheet]]s.

title: vampire_(azur_lane)
body:
[[Azur Lane]]'s personification of the destroyer HMAS [i]Vampire[/i] (pennant number D68). Character designed by [[Saru]], voiced by [[Kugimiya Rie]]. 

In real life, she was originally a [[Royal Navy]] destroyer before being sold to Australia. In Azur Lane, the Royal Navy faction combines all the canon Commonwealth navies into a single faction so she keeps her HMS [i]Vampire[/i] name from 1917-1933.
